Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2011 09:49PM ksingh0 wrote: I have been on taxotere for just over 1 year. It has done a great job on both my liver and bone mets. I get it once a week with 3 weeks on and 1 week break. Different than the normal schedule because I had many rare SE's. This has helped schedule helped with my SE's. My onc and I didn't want to go off of it because it was working so well. Tumor markers way down, CTC is a 1, bone mets look like scar now on scans, liver mets worst case regression and best case scar tissue (debate on scan depending who reads it). I did do taxol for stage 3 and had less side effects. I know we are all different but thought I would share.... Good luck in your decision.

I hope banana bread counts!!!! :) =) Kelly

I am so glad it is working and hope it is working for you too!! Kelly

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 06:03AM ksingh0 wrote: PJB, I was on taxotere for a year and had 10 thora's.  They provide great relief.  My fluid was clear on my test and the thought was they were caused by Taxotere.  I am now on Halaven and still geting them. I am going in for a VAT very soon (trying to schedule it).  My fliud will be tested again.  I am nervous too.  The thought is either malignant cells in there or damage to lungs because on taxotere sooooo long (14 months). I the your thora will be so worth it have some advil or tylenonl around for after.  I had some irritation after as my lung expanded and thought it was mildly painful.   Good Luck and hugs! Kelly
Posts.Title: What should I expect from draining effusion? PJB mungie

Posts.Content: May 12, 2011 10:11AM - edited May 12, 2011 10:12AM by ksingh0 Kim, Thank you for starting this thread.  I thought I was the only one with terrible nail issues and neuropathy in my fingers and toes.  Although I don't like to know others have this yuck it is nice not to feel alone.  I lost almost all my fingernails eventually and my onc finally agreed to let me get acrylics because I couldn't stand the looks I got from people all the time - being bald is enough.  I do ice my hands and feet and I seem to go through cycles where they start to heal and look better and then they lift and ooze again. I still ice as it seems to help the pain and keep them better longer.  I also soak my fingers in hydrogen peroxide to keep them from getting infected.  On the really high lifted ones I will sometimes but neosporin (sp?) underneath to keep them from getting infected.  Someone suggested tea tree oil but I hate the smell.  My toes are a nightmare and they look so yucky.  I love flip flops and sandals so I need to find some summer shoes that don't show off the toes.  =)

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 10:48PM ksingh0 wrote: Paula, I just had the talc procedure done last week.  I was in the hospital for 8 days and needed a second injection of talc.   It is worth it for sure.  I go back in a few weeks for my ohter side.  Taxotere was the hypothesis for my PE's too.  But when I went off taxotere they didn't go away.  No cancer found anywhere (not in fluid, pleura or lungs).  Now they think started by taxotere and my body just keeps up with the inflamatory response and needed to be glued together to sotp it. It is a bit uncomfortable to have the drain tube and my side still feels pretty bruised.  Still worth it.  PM me if you want more surgery details.  Good luck! Kelly

Posts.Title: Now HERE is some encouragement!! Lynn1 Kellke

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 03:34PM ksingh0 wrote: Jenn, I am so sorry to hear about the progression.  This disease stinks!! I haven't been on your chemo combo so I can't comment on SE's.  I did want to let you know I had a REALLY hard time leaving work too.  It was a struggle and this is when I had to actually see a therapist.  This made me feel so defeated, like the cancer was winning.  Fast forward to now...  I am so happy to be off of work and focusing on my health, family, and friends.  I am so glad to be away from the stress of work (even though I loved it!!).  I believe it has helped me with my overall well being. I still miss work sometimes but not in a bad way - just miss my friends so I schedule dinner with them and they catch me up on things.  Also, STD and LTD were a real blessing and just got SSDI approved in 1 week.   Good luck!! I hope the combo works wonders.  I also am sending lots of cyber hugs and support your way.
Posts.Title: MORE Progression........... jenn3 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: ksingh0 wrote: I wanted to share my great news.  I got my CT scan results and it showed regression in my liver.  HOORAY!!!!  I am sooo thrilled. My confusion is that the last CT report said that the liver lesions looked like "scar tissue from effective chemotherapy treatment" and this report had no mention of scar tissue.  I asked the onc and he said it is all depends on who reads the scan and he was thrilled with the results (as I am too).   I was thinking of pushing for a PET next time to get a more clear understanding of the liver and bone situation.  Or should I just leave it alone and be content with my results as they are....  I just really like to have all the info. Sooo excited about the regression!!  Kelly Dx 5/17/2010, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 08:55AM ksingh0 wrote: Jenn, I just wanted to let you know that I had very rapid spread and liver involvement too.  It was pretty bad and they told me to get prepared and at best had little time left.  After freaking out, I decided not to listen and just fight it.  I started taxotere and xeloda (still on taxotere) and last scan and counts were good (looked like just scar tissue left).  There is hope if it is in the liver. I hope that the treatments knock the cancer back down.  As for the financial stuff - I couldn't work with my treatments and I don't regret it.  The time with my family and friends has been great but I have been very blessed with good benefits from work so I haven't had to worry as much as I could have...

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 07:23PM ksingh0 wrote: Kadyann, My onc was really on top of it.   The second I said my eyes were watering a lot he sent me to the eye specialist.  What they did was a quick evaluation of my eyes and tear ducts.  They determined they were blocked and then tried to "unblock" them in the office with some tools and numbing drops.  That didn't work and they scheduled surgery for the stints.  If they are too scared they have to construct new tear ducts.  The eye doc said the chemo not only caused the scar tissue but it also caused dry eyes which makes you tear more and makes the problem worse.   My eyes watered 24/7 and got the salt build up.  I even looked like a raccoon because the skin around my eyes got a red burn. The eye doc spoke like he evaluated many women on BC chemo treatments for blocked tear ducts.  Luckily, I had a quick surgery for the stints (under twilight sleep, not fully out). Feel free to PM me if you want more info.
Posts.Title: Watery Eyes??? mommyx3 Elizabeth1959

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 05:28PM ksingh0 wrote: Hi.  I had this watering eye problem on Taxotere.  Mine was due to scar tissue build up on outside of tear ducts.  I had to have stints put in.  I am much better!!  I still have issues if I get a sinus infection but drops help clear it up.  I would reco seeing an eye doc. if the other suggestions here don't work. My onc recommended one that he knew who did this procedure often. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Watery Eyes??? mommyx3 Elizabeth1959

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 07:25PM ksingh0 wrote: Just wanted to add that I have a real eye phobia and the stints are not bad at all.  After a few days I didn't even know they were there.  =)
Posts.Title: Watery Eyes??? mommyx3 Elizabeth1959

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 07:55AM - edited Apr 12, 2011 08:21AM by ksingh0 Dawn, I know all onc's are different and have different ways of treating.  My onc prefers to keep you on a chemo until it fails.  "If it ain't broke don't fix it" kind of thing. If I tell him my QOL is not what I want it to be then he will of course stop any treatment and start a new one.  He is a strong believer in constant treatment.  But as I said before I think there are different views on that and not sure that either way is right or wrong.  I know that my current onc has a reputation for being very aggressive in particular with Stage 4.  This is why I chose him when I switched. I think you should have a long discussion with your onc on May 9th.  Or ask to talk to them beforehand if it helps.  If it is making you this stressed and anxious I would question, question, question them until you feel comfortable.  As you said in your post it is your life not theirs.   There is also nothing wrong with getting a second opinion from another onc.  Good luck and (((hugs))) sent your way.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 02:28PM - edited Apr 8, 2011 04:00PM by ksingh0 Hi Patti, I am not sure about the answer to your question.  My onc seems to share the same opinion as your onc.  I only have CT scans and CTC bloodwork.  If anything is questionable then he orders other tests like PET or MRI.  Although at the beginning he did all of the tests: CT, bone, PET, MRI, and brain MRI.  I have always looked at it as a blessing - less time in the hospital or imaging center.   Kelly
Posts.Title: CT vs. PET or MRI pteney pteney

Posts.Content: ksingh0 wrote: Hello. I am new to posting so not sure if this is the right area or not. I am stage III, with IDC in the right breast and extensive DCIS, DCIS in the left breast, and BRCA 2+. I am currently in neo-adjuvant chemo (12x taxol, 4x DD AC). I am scheduled for radiation (6 weeks, on right side only) after a bi-lateral mastectomy. I have been interviewing PS's and have gotten conflicting info. Some reco waiting for recon (expander and implant on left and Latissimus Muscle Flap with expander and implant on right) for 3 months post rads. Others have suggested skin saving mastectomy with expanders put in immediately but not filling them until rads is complete. I am not a canidate for the TRAM flap. Anyone out there gone through this and have any advice? Thanks =) Kelly Kelly Dx 5/17/2010, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
